title: Science Aspirations and Career Choice:Age 10-14
abstractText:
There is widespread concern that not enough young people are choosing to study Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) after the age of 16 and that the profile of those who do go on to pursue STEM subjects and careers remains too narrow, especially in the physical sciences and engineering.

ASPIRES sought to shed new light on how young peopleâ€™s aspirations develop over this 10-14 age period, exploring what influences the likelihood of a young person aspiring to a science-related career. The study asks:

  •     How are student aspirations formed over time?
  •     What influences the development of aspirations?
  •     How are aspirations shaped by gender, social class and ethnicity?

ASPIRES combined online surveys of a student cohort and repeat interviews with a sub-sample of students and their parents. Data were collected at three time points:

  1. Year 6 (age 10/11)
  2. year 8 (age 12/13)
  3. Year 9 (age 13/14).

In total, over 19,000 surveys were completed (9,319, Y6; 5,634, Y8 and 4,600, Y9). 85 students and 63 parents were also repeatedly interviewed from Y6 to Y9. We also worked with a small group of London teachers to develop approaches for integrating STEM careers information into Key Stage 3 Science lessons.
findingsText:
1. Most young people have high aspirations - just not for science

The ASPIRES research found that, on the whole, most young people aged 10-14 hold relatively high aspirations for professional, managerial and technical careers. We did not find evidence of a 'poverty of aspirations' among students or parents - almost all students reported that their parents value education and want them to do well.
